item.title: ‚ÄúBrother Jeff‚Äôs Cultural Center passed out more than 1,600...
item.content:encoded:
Representative Leslie Herod

‚ÄúBrother Jeff‚Äôs Cultural Center passed out more than 1,600 free meals on Martin Luther King, Jr. Day. The act of service stretched from Five Points to Montbello and even Aurora, as people came together to honor his legacy.‚Äù

Brother Jeff‚Äôs Cultural Center passed out more than 1,600 free meals on Martin Luther King, Jr. Day.

Representative Leslie Herod

Looking for something to do today? Check this out!

‚ÄúThe Boulder theater company's virtual production will offer music, slam poetry, and readings of autobiographical monologues penned by formerly incarcerated Coloradans.‚Äù

The Boulder theater company's virtual production will include autobiographical monologues penned by formerly incarcerated Coloradans.

item.title: ‚ÄúWhy is equality so assiduously avoided? Why does white...
item.content:encoded:
Representative Leslie Herod

‚ÄúWhy is equality so assiduously avoided? Why does white America delude itself, and how does it rationalize the evil it retains?

The majority of white Americans consider themselves sincerely committed to justice for the Negro. They believe that American society is essentially hospitable to fair play and to steady growth toward a middle-class Utopia embodying racial harmony. But unfortunately this is a fantasy of self-deception and comfortable vanity.‚Äù

Dr. King ...
‚Äî Where Do We Go From Here, 1967

See More
item.author: Leslie Herod

item.title: ‚ÄúThe Michigan Attorney General's Office Thursday...
item.content:encoded:
Representative Leslie Herod

‚ÄúThe Michigan Attorney General's Office Thursday announced criminal charges for eight former state officials, including the state's former Gov. Rick Snyder, along with one current official, for their alleged roles in the Flint water crisis.‚Äù NPR

Together the group faces 42 counts related to the drinking water catastrophe roughly seven years ago. The crimes range from perjury to misconduct in office to involuntary manslaughter.

npr.org

Ex-Michigan Gov. Rick Snyder And 8 Others Criminally Charged In Flint Water Crisis

Together the group faces 42 counts related to the drinking water catastrophe roughly seven years ago. The crimes range from perjury to misconduct in office to involuntary manslaughter.Together the group faces 42 counts related to the drinking water catastrophe roughly seven years ago. The crimes range from perjury to misconduct in office to involuntary manslaughter.
item.author: Leslie Herod

item.title: ‚ÄúThe divisiveness is clear. Today was the first time that we...
item.content:encoded:
Representative Leslie Herod

‚ÄúThe divisiveness is clear. Today was the first time that we voted for our speaker by a recorded vote on the floor, which is something that‚Äôs never happened before,‚Äù Herod said. ‚ÄúIt is more divisive, but it doesn‚Äôt stop us from doing the work that we need to get done.‚Äù

Denver7

Colorado lawmakers convened Wednesday to mark the start of the 2021 legislative session. The day was absent of the normal pomp and circumstance.

thedenverchannel.com

Colorado lawmakers convene for a 'soft-opening' to the 2021 legislative session

Colorado lawmakers convened Wednesday to mark the start of the 2021 legislative session. The day was absent of the normal pomp and circumstance.Colorado lawmakers convened Wednesday to mark the start of the 2021 legislative session. The day was absent of the normal pomp and circumstance.
item.author: Leslie Herod

item.title: "Herod and other state lawmakers had pushed to end...
item.content:encoded:
Representative Leslie Herod

"Herod and other state lawmakers had pushed to end qualified immunity earlier in the year, but their efforts had petered out. It wasn‚Äôt until Floyd‚Äôs tragic death and the renewed attention on the 2019 Aurora, Colorado, police killing of 23-year-old Elijah McClain that momentum for Herod‚Äôs legislation really grew.

‚ÄúWe‚Äôve had tragic killings before, but this was the first time we‚Äôve seen the international public outcry,‚Äù Herod told COURIER in an interview. ‚ÄúFolks from across C...olorado were engaged in [Senate Bill] 217 and calling for its passage. That was something I hadn‚Äôt quite seen of that magnitude before, and we‚Äôre just very honored that it got passed.‚Äù

Herod expressed pride that the bill was the first of its kind in the nation to be enacted into law.

‚ÄúI think what we showed folks is that we can do more and that we can work on policing and should work on policing and take these very definitive steps in keeping our community safe and ensuring the integrity of law enforcement,‚Äù Herod said."

Courier

See MoreState lawmakers worked to reform policing, expand rights for LGBTQ residents, and reduce drug costs, among other measures.

couriernewsroom.com

Progressives Notched Big Wins at the State Level This Year. Here Are a Few.

State lawmakers worked to reform policing, expand rights for LGBTQ residents, and reduce drug costs, among other measures.State lawmakers worked to reform policing, expand rights for LGBTQ residents, and reduce drug costs, among other measures.
item.author: Leslie Herod

item.title: ‚ÄúOn Jan. 5, the state recorded 1,043 new cases in Denver. On...
item.content:encoded:
Representative Leslie Herod

‚ÄúOn Jan. 5, the state recorded 1,043 new cases in Denver. On the previous day, just 172 new infections were recorded. Jan. 4 also happened to be the first day restaurants were allowed to re-open in Denver, and elsewhere in Colorado, after Gov. Polis eased restrictions.

‚ÄúWe have unfortunately seen an uptick in cases, and it‚Äôs most likely attributed to holiday gatherings,‚Äù read a prepared statement in an email from the state‚Äôs Joint Information Center, which did not specify who wrote the message. ‚ÄúIt‚Äôs too soon to tell if it‚Äôs just a momentary increase or if it‚Äôs an indication of a more significant, sustained spike.‚Äù

Denverite

...all while the city and state are opening back up for business.

denverite.com

Denver is in the middle of a post-Christmas COVID spike

...all while the city and state are opening back up for business....all while the city and state are opening back up for business.
item.author: Leslie Herod

item.title: ‚ÄúThe Bill also provides $7.5 million for direct relief...
item.content:encoded:
Representative Leslie Herod

‚ÄúThe Bill also provides $7.5 million for direct relief payments to eligible artists, crew members and arts organizations.

Those payments will be allocated by the creative industries division in the Colorado office of economic development. There is also $4 million in the Bill, to provide direct relief payments, grants, loans, technical assistance and consulting support to minority-owned businesses. ‚Äú

Arvada Press

State Senate Bill 20B-001, passed in December‚Äôs extraordinary three-day legislative session, should soon yield a bit of financial relief for some Jeffco small businesses hurt by Covid restrictions. ‚Ä¶

goldentranscript.net

Help for Jeffco small businesses on the way

State Senate Bill 20B-001, passed in December‚Äôs extraordinary three-day legislative session, should soon yield a bit of financial relief for some Jeffco small businesses hurt by Covid restrictions. ‚Ä¶State Senate Bill 20B-001, passed in December‚Äôs extraordinary three-day legislative session, should soon yield a bit of financial relief for some Jeffco small businesses hurt by Covid restrictions. ‚Ä¶
item.author: Leslie Herod

item.title: ‚ÄúRepresentative Andy Kim, a New Jersey Democrat, saw a certain...
item.content:encoded:
Representative Leslie Herod

‚ÄúRepresentative Andy Kim, a New Jersey Democrat, saw a certain arrogance in what the rioters did. ‚ÄúWhen people storm in ‚Äî literally break down the door of America and desecrate this temple of our democracy and this flag ‚Äî it shows that they think they‚Äôre bigger than this country,‚Äù he said. ‚ÄúThey think they‚Äôre better than our institutions.‚Äù

The violence caused by a pro-Trump mob on Wednesday has shaken many who work at the Capitol. And some people of color say the law enforcement response reopened old wounds.

nytimes.com

Rampage Weighs on Congressional Staff Members and Capitol Workers

The violence caused by a pro-Trump mob on Wednesday has shaken many who work at the Capitol. And some people of color say the law enforcement response reopened old wounds.The violence caused by a pro-Trump mob on Wednesday has shaken many who work at the Capitol. And some people of color say the law enforcement response reopened old wounds.
item.author: Leslie Herod

item.title: ‚ÄúThe fridge outside Norris‚Äô book store and coffee shop is...
item.content:encoded:
Representative Leslie Herod

‚ÄúThe fridge outside Norris‚Äô book store and coffee shop is one of three that launched last month in central Denver neighborhoods through Denver Community Fridge. Two more have been providing free food since Dec. 5 outside Base Coat Nail Salon (27th and Walnut streets in Five Points) and Huckleberry Roasters (North Pecos and 43rd Avenue in Sunnyside).

A fourth Denver Community Fridge will debut on Jan. 10, at Amethyst Coffee Company, 4999 W. 44th Ave. near Lakeside Amusement Park, Zain said, with more planned for Capitol Hill and East Colfax Avenue.‚Äù
The Know by Denver Post Entertainment

Denver Community Fridge gives Denverites free food in front of businesses like Mutiny Info Cafe, Base Coat Nails and Huckleberry Coffee.

theknow.denverpost.com

Denver will soon have four art-covered fridges offering free food for anyone who needs it

Denver Community Fridge gives Denverites free food in front of businesses like Mutiny Info Cafe, Base Coat Nails and Huckleberry Coffee.Denver Community Fridge gives Denverites free food in front of businesses like Mutiny Info Cafe, Base Coat Nails and Huckleberry Coffee.
item.author: Leslie Herod

item.title: "Herod said that if Black protestors had attempted to storm...
item.content:encoded:
Representative Leslie Herod

"Herod said that if Black protestors had attempted to storm the U.S. Capitol, they wouldn‚Äôt have gotten as far.

‚ÄúBreaching the Capitol was not an option for someone who looks like me. I remember back in 2013, when a woman drove past the barricade ‚Äî a Black woman ‚Äî was shot and killed,‚Äù Herod said.

She said that even if the police were not in fact colluding with the mobs, they at least weren‚Äôt as prepared as they were during the BLM protests over the summer, indicating to her ...that they did not take the insurrectionists as seriously as a threat as they did people of color chanting for justice.

There is an obvious explanation for that disparity, she said.

‚ÄúWhat I‚Äôve learned in my life is that the obvious answer is probably the right one,‚Äù Herod said. ‚ÄúAnd the obvious is that it is white supremacy, it is racism, and it is discrimination, that allows those people to storm the Capitol to make it to the Senate floor, to make it into Speaker Pelosi‚Äôs office, mostly unscathed and free.‚Äù

Denverite

See MoreActivists say that the Capitol police‚Äôs seemingly lax treatment of insurrectionists reflects racial dynamics that exist here in Denver.

denverite.com

For Denver activists and lawmakers, police response to attack on U.S. Capitol highlights disparity in treatment of Black and brown protestors

Activists say that the Capitol police‚Äôs seemingly lax treatment of insurrectionists reflects racial dynamics that exist here in Denver.Activists say that the Capitol police‚Äôs seemingly lax treatment of insurrectionists reflects racial dynamics that exist here in Denver.
item.author: Leslie Herod

item.title: SB217 is now the law in Colorado, please comply. "Given the...
item.content:encoded:
Representative Leslie Herod

SB217 is now the law in Colorado, please comply. "Given the newfound ability of people to hold officers accountable in state courts for violations of rights, ‚Äúthe Court finds Defendant‚Äôs attempt to construe them as federal claims bizarre and inapt,‚Äù U.S. District Judge Raymond P. Moore wrote in a two-page Nov. 4 order."

Citing Colorado‚Äôs police accountability law enacted in the wake of nationwide racial justice protests last summer, a judge rejected an attempt from the Commerce City Police Department to hear a

coloradopolitics.com

Federal judge sends use-of-force claim back to state court, pointing to new police accountability law

Citing Colorado‚Äôs police accountability law enacted in the wake of nationwide racial justice protests last summer, a judge rejected an attempt from the Commerce City Police Department to hear aCiting Colorado‚Äôs police accountability law enacted in the wake of nationwide racial justice protests last summer, a judge rejected an attempt from the Commerce City Police Department to hear a
item.author: Leslie Herod

item.title: "This was a catastrophic security failure. If this were a...
item.content:encoded:
Representative Leslie Herod

"This was a catastrophic security failure. If this were a military operation, the officers in charge of that operation would‚Äôve been relieved of command on the spot. There has got to be accountability here. It never should‚Äôve happened. Nobody can reconcile the way that we treated Black Lives Matter protesters from this summer with armored vehicles and cordons of National Guard troops on the steps of the Lincoln Monument, with the fact that in a matter of half an hour, this mob was able to breach the shrine of democracy and heart of government and take it over the way they did. I‚Äôm angry and there‚Äôs got to be accountability."

Jason Crow Rolling Stone

Rep. Jason Crow‚Äôs firsthand account from the House of Representatives when the mob breached the Capitol: ‚ÄúI was certain at that point we would have to fight our way out, and so I resolv‚Ä¶

rollingstone.com

'I Called My Wife and Told Her I Loved Her': One Congressman's Story From Inside a Capitol Under Attack

Rep. Jason Crow‚Äôs firsthand account from the House of Representatives when the mob breached the Capitol: ‚ÄúI was certain at that point we would have to fight our way out, and so I resolv‚Ä¶Rep. Jason Crow‚Äôs firsthand account from the House of Representatives when the mob breached the Capitol: ‚ÄúI was certain at that point we would have to fight our way out, and so I resolv‚Ä¶
item.author: Leslie Herod

item.title: "The plan, dubbed ‚ÄúWaste No More,‚Äù would require all...
item.content:encoded:
Representative Leslie Herod

"The plan, dubbed ‚ÄúWaste No More,‚Äù would require all businesses ‚Äî apartments, condos, restaurants, hospitals, hotels and sporting arenas, to name a few of many ‚Äî to provide compost and recycling pickup services. State law prohibits the city from collecting compost and recycling at large apartment buildings and commercial properties."

Denverite

The ballot initiative is aimed at slowing the charge of climate change.

denverite.com

Voters might decide whether to make apartment buildings and businesses compost and recycle their waste

The ballot initiative is aimed at slowing the charge of climate change.The ballot initiative is aimed at slowing the charge of climate change.
item.author: Leslie Herod

item.title: ‚ÄúThis was a failure of that police department this should have...
item.content:encoded:
Representative Leslie Herod

‚ÄúThis was a failure of that police department this should have never happened,‚Äù said Colorado state Rep. Leslie Herod. ‚ÄúIt felt like there was an open door for this coup.‚Äù

Another frustrating element for Black social justice advocates watching the news unfold Wednesday, was the images of how police treated Trump supporters, compared to how the advocates were treated over the summer.

‚ÄúI saw today on the videos, law enforcement officers taking selfies with the protestors, I did... not see rubber bullets and flash bangs and teargas until, frankly, nighttime,‚Äù Herod said.‚Äù

FOX31 KDVR.com

See MoreThe images from Wednesday‚Äôs attack on the center of American democracy, outlines a tale of two Americas for social justice advocates who watched it unfold on their TV and phone.

kdvr.com

Black leaders say police response to Capitol attack shows double standard

The images from Wednesday‚Äôs attack on the center of American democracy, outlines a tale of two Americas for social justice advocates who watched it unfold on their TV and phone.The images from Wednesday‚Äôs attack on the center of American democracy, outlines a tale of two Americas for social justice advocates who watched it unfold on their TV and phone.
item.author: Leslie Herod

item.title: ‚ÄúEmission reductions from transportation, the state‚Äôs...
item.content:encoded:
Representative Leslie Herod

‚ÄúEmission reductions from transportation, the state‚Äôs largest source of greenhouse gas emissions, and buildings have been scaled back, while more emphasis has been placed on curbing emissions from power plants and oil and gas operations.‚Äù

The Colorado Sun

Critics say the governor's roadmap is guided by "wishful thinking" rather than binding mandates to cut emissions blamed for climate change.

coloradosun.com

Colorado is behind on targets to cut greenhouse gas emissions. How far should the state push industry to get there?

Critics say the governor's roadmap is guided by "wishful thinking" rather than binding mandates to cut emissions blamed for climate change.Critics say the governor's roadmap is guided by "wishful thinking" rather than binding mandates to cut emissions blamed for climate change.
item.author: Leslie Herod

item.title: The insurrection taking place at our nation‚Äôs Capitol today is...
item.content:encoded:
Representative Leslie Herod

The insurrection taking place at our nation‚Äôs Capitol today is a feeble, repulsive attempt to overthrow our democracy. The terrorists cannot and will not prevail. Our country held a fair election and the voters have spoken. It is our duty to listen.

I stand with President-elect Biden in his call for the violence at the U.S. Capitol and at state capitols around the country to end, now. Together, we will restore the soul of our nation.
item.author: Leslie Herod

item.title: ‚ÄúThe idea, which pre-dates the pandemic, has been expanded in...
item.content:encoded:
Representative Leslie Herod

‚ÄúThe idea, which pre-dates the pandemic, has been expanded in Denver and across the country because of COVID‚Äôs impact on the economy. More traditional pantries ‚Äì the kind you might find in a church basement ‚Äì and food banks have seen a dramatic increase in people coming to collect food. The Denver Department of Public Health & Environment had estimated that before the pandemic, 11 percent of the city‚Äôs population struggled to access food some or most of the time. By this past summer, the estimate had increased to 25 percent.‚Äù

Denverite

A food-sharing idea that pre-dates the pandemic has been expanded in Denver and across the country because of COVID‚Äôs impact on the economy.

denverite.com

Sidewalk pantries are a way for neighbors, businesses and churches to help during COVID

A food-sharing idea that pre-dates the pandemic has been expanded in Denver and across the country because of COVID‚Äôs impact on the economy.A food-sharing idea that pre-dates the pandemic has been expanded in Denver and across the country because of COVID‚Äôs impact on the economy.
item.author: Leslie Herod

item.title: Incredibly humbled by this feature in 5280 and honored to have...
item.content:encoded:
Representative Leslie Herod

Incredibly humbled by this feature in 5280 and honored to have community support for this work. We all have a story to tell. Our stories are our strength and our voices will be heard.
